The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?

Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations

What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class
Comments_List: I learned so much!
The process of developing management plans, how to go about organizing the sequence of work as one area guides other areas. Also, developing client interaction skills.
Practical, on the ground forest management skills.
All the skills.

Interacting with clients, and understanding every aspect of land management, including definition of goals, bedrock geology, hydrology, soils, site classification, vegetation inventory, stand delineation, social context / stakeholder analysis, working within a team, recommending management alternatives, and presenting work.

I gained a lot of knowledge, skills and insightsmore than in any other course. I learned a lot about how to develop a management plan for a client, which in my case was for wildlife conservation. We conducted a biophysical assessment, for which I learned how to identify understory plants, overstory plants, and soils. I learned how to read a landscape. I learned how to conduct a deed survey, a social assessment, and craft a land use history timeline for the property. We made management recommendations. And along the way, we learned and utilized many other skills that are too many to list.

I learned so much in this class. A few things that stand out are how to learn the history of a landscape from multiple perspectives and contexts, how to tailor an inventory to the goals at hand, and how to reconcile various values/objectives/histories with each other into a comprehensive plan. The process of writing a management plan like this was really intensive and helped me gain so many skills that I'll use later on.
this class is amazing. I learned a little bit about everything I will need to know in a real-world professional setting.
I felt like a finally became knowledgeable enough in to work as a forester.

I developed all the basic skills I would need to comprehensively assess a New England property and how to move it to meet required objectives: assessing soils, hydrology, species composition, forest health, history, and current social context. I also gained a strong baseline to develop my skills independently to assess other properties in with different biophysical and historical context.

Many and they would escape the full scope of this evaluation. In short, I pretty much learnt everything I had set out myself to learn in terms of the many components of a land management plan, particularly in what relates to how social approaches interrelate to ecological contexts in the field. I wish there was more time for local dendrology, which is crammed-up at the beginning of the course (it could be spread out or even given little by little from day one), but even so I feel I really learnt my own, particularly in terms of families and invasives. It was an accomplishment. Also in terms learning the fundamentals of forest health assessment and of applying lessons from the Practice of Silviculture class to this one, it is really, really, outstandingit almost comes across as seamlessly integrated. While useful, the forestry knowledge was a bit too much biased on the forestry side, but that's what it is and I am proud to have learnt the basics about that tooas a natural resource manager I feel as if I did acquire a baseline to understand many management issues and to effectively communicate with other professionals in the field--particularly foresters. At all this, the course excels and pretty much met all of my expectations.
This course provided a synthesis of all that I have learned as a forestry student and laid bare areas in which I have come up short. I think that this course should be required for all MFs.

Where to begin. In addition to learning like a semester's worth of information on geology, soils, deeds, land use history, plant species, site assessments, silviculture, etc etc. in the first ~1.5 months of the class, I also strengthened skills in working with land owners, collecting and analyzing data, creating maps and figures, and compiling a large document, among many many other skills and insights.
Very well.
Exceeded.
Quite well. My expectations if anything were exceeded. What an amazing course.
The knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class exceeded my expectations. I learned much more and came away creating a management plan that was much greater than I had expected.
They met my expectations, and even sometimes exceeded them. I knew that this would be a really important class I'd get a lot out of, but I still learned more from the process than I thought I would.
Great! I expected to learn a LOT and to be challenged, and I did learn a lot and was challenged while also being supported.
They exceeded my expectations.
Very well and more than I expected.
See previous answer.
Very well.

I'm not sure I wholly comprehended just what this class would entail at the beginning of the semester, so in many ways it met my expectations and in many ways it did not. Overall, though, I would say the knowledge, skills, and insights I gained aligned with my expectations and probably surpassed them in most cases out of necessity to meet the demands of this course. That said, I thought I would have a lot of opportunities to learn new skills, but when push came to shove, I ended up strengthening skills I already had instead of spending time to learn new ones. Having each group member do things they already knew how to do was more efficient than having us learn new skills given the time crunch of the course.

I wished that the bio assessment and sampling methodology lectures were provided way before students begin to visit their property. A lot of students were unaware of how to measure for understory and canopy, so giving a lecture about it before would have been very helpful. I also wished that the work load was a bit less.

I feel that the all the course material should be released at the beginning of the semester to access and reference if someone wanted to get ahead of the workload. I think we need to spend more time on soils of other series than the QCI region. Also, maybe discuss the costs associated with each part of the management plan (how much to charge, worth, etc).

Some of the lectures were very drawn out and hard to engage with. It seemed like some of them were unnecessary (e.g. the full lecture on the quiet corner initiative) and many could be greatly streamlined.
Maybe make sure MEMs know what they are getting into?

I am pretty sure that this is the most challenging course at FES, but it is likewise the most rewarding. I am so thankful that I took this class. The only thing I can think of to improve the class, pick a site closer to New Haven (once the Quiet Corner mission is completed, of course).

The course prepares you to be a professional forester or conservation planner, which itself is invaluable. However, the means to the end was, in my opinion, more challenging than it needed to be.  I (and many others agree) that this course should be broken down into two semesters. The course materials, knowledge, and skills were too compacted into a short amount of time, such that at times, we would learn the skills and knowledge after it was too latewe had passed that stage of the assessment or planning. For example, our deadline to submit our sampling design plan was October 10th, and we started conducting our sampling over the next two weeks. However, we did not learn about the pros and cons of variable-radius plots versus fixed-area plots until October 24th in the Data Analysis lecture. As someone who has never designed sampling methods for conducting a biophysical assessment, not having the skills to weigh my options between the fixed-area versus variable-radius plots was immensely frustrating.  As another example, a central component of our property's land use history was logging and managed wood lots. However, it wasn't until the very last day of being in the field for sampling that we learned how to identify stumps by species or genus... This skill would have added a lot of color to our land use history, had we had the skill at the start of our sampling... Finally, the compact nature of the course meant that students had to learn soil identification, plant identification, site classification, and stand delineation all within the span of three weeks. While this was an impressive feat and was necessary for conducting field sampling, the cramming nature of the course took away from our ability to fully absorb the content we were expected to learn. I felt less than fully prepared when launching into conducting our fieldwork, and a slower, more intentional pace would enable us to focus refine our skills before jumping to the next (or two or three).

This misalignment of timing between learning skills and knowledge and implementing those skills and knowledge (which often preceded the former or was subsequent to a hasty lesson that fails to go over all the necessary skills and considerations) was characteristic for this course. I strongly believe that this course would benefit from being taught over two semesters, to ensure that students have the necessary skills and knowledge needed to prepare them for their independent fieldwork. The course need not be evenly distributed in 3 unit increments, but perhaps learning about sampling methods, data analysis, and developing a sampling planor learning about the soil, geology, hydrology, and plant speciesa semester before could better prepare us for our fieldwork, relieve some of the intensity, and enable us to digest the content as we're conducting our assessments and recommendations.

This management plan is a ton of work, but the class provided a good structure for getting it done. I appreciated having deadlines throughout the semester, because even though we were all still scrambling at the end, it could have been much worse. The main strength of this class is getting to work on a real property with real landowners to write a real plan that they can learn from. It's so great to get to know a place and its people to that extent, and to get to be part of their decision making.

One thing that could be changed is that the course doesn't provide much insight into the type of management plan that many of us might write in the future -- less elaborate and detailed than the ones we did for this class. I think it would have been helpful to have a small segment going over which components of what we did would be included in that type of plan, just so that we can contextualize the work of the class.

Another thing I might change is the structure of the exams at the beginning of the semester. I think a lot of us delayed starting work on our plans because the exams were so much work, and it would have been nice to integrate those a bit more somehow.
It is great
Strengths are: hands on experiences doing real forestry work. Weaknesses are: the actual lectures at times were not always helpful.
It's an enormous workload and very time consuming. Prior knowledge of tree ID, silviculture, and GIS (at least map-making) would be very handy.

Ironically, the main weakness of the course is also its main strength, which is that it tries to teach how to do a land management plan in just one semester (actually "doing" it in pretty much three month's time), while at the same time mixing together students with different backgrounds and expertisesome with advanced knowledge of the ecosystems and species of the context where the class is taught and the management plans are done. So, the time scope and the student composition are both the best and worst aspects of the course.

In terms of time scope, it seems rather ambitious to thoroughly study a place over just a few months, particularly in social or ethnographic terms. Rapid rural assessments in particular are increasingly linked to extractivist and colonial "parachuting" approaches to natural and human ecosystems, and so timing should be reassessed in those terms (I.e. by splitting the class into two 3-credit ones, see more below). Not that it cannot be done (although everyone carries on work on management plans beyond the semester), but looking back there are many drawbacks from cramming all 6 credits in a single semester while there's much to be gained from splitting the course in two (see more below).

In terms of student composition, I found it very, very enriching (to say the least) to have had the luck of being paired with experienced foresters (or foresters, which I am not). It provided continuous learning from my peers and I am sure that this went both ways in terms of other skill sets in which I had more experience and knowledge than they. However, as with the timing, there are two downsides to this. First, that it may well be that not every team had the same advantage. Second, that more experienced folk are unchallenged by reviewing stuff they already know (like local dendrology) and have few incentives to tackle new stuff (like social ecology). Moreover, in the case of Foresters, they find themselves doing quite a large amount of work for this not being a capstone for them. On the other hand, outsiders or those with different backgrounds find the experience challenging throughout. 

A way to go around this would be to have experienced folk arrive at the course with some sort of advance placement or to have them skip part of the course. They could be formally appointed as "team forester", skip part of the course credits (or do the course half-time) or otherwise spare them the lecture time, at the very least. This is just one idea, as how I would rally go around this would be to split the course in two: one would tackle general aspects of land management (or all those that apply regardless of context) and the second one would go into context-specific contents and to the actual production of the land management plan itself (and this one could be a four-credit course). The idea is two-fold: first you save some time to more experienced folk and second, you open the door to other teachers to offer the second part of the seminar in contexts other than the Quite Corner Initiative. 

This second aspect addresses the most limiting aspect of the course, which is that being set in northeastern Connecticut, it greatly limits the scope of land management to a handful of goal variations among its real-life clients. There are also other management contexts in Connecticut that could well provide many different experiencesmostly coastal ecosystems and urban ecologythus splitting the course in two could cater to other instructors with a mindset  different to just forestry. My two cents.

Different groups faced different challenges during the creation of their management plans, which the instructors dealt with fairly deftly. Perhaps a survey of past classes could be used to provide diverse timelines for students whose property owners have different objectives.

I've debated all semester about how this class could be improved to take less of a toll on its students. I know that the workload is part of the right of passage of taking this class, but it really did come at a cost to my physical and mental health. For one, I think landowners and properties should be selected as potential projects with care, placing guidelines/restrictions on how much a landowner can ask of the (free) student (labor) and possibly how big the property is. Students can have very different semesters depending on who they work with, and it perhaps would be more reasonable to limit landowners to one or two key objectives/goals... as opposed to the ~10 that my landowner had, for a very large property. Secondly, I think it's worth considering making this course two semesters long. Logistically this could be difficult, but cramming so much in one semester limits the potential of this class. And apparently a lot of students are forced to make this class two semesters anyway, working on their management plans well into the spring semester but for no pay or course credit. This would give students more time to learn the fundamentals (instead of, for example, having to learn >100 plant species in a week). Alternatively, this course should have some strict prerequisites besides a seemingly meaningless application process. The strength of the class lies in its teaching team and the real-world experience it provides working with actual landowners. Despite the toll of this class, I learned a heck of a lot from it, and that truly is to the credit of Dr. Ashton and Jess Wikle, who clearly care a lot about their students and courses.
Time management is very important for this class.
Be prepared to work, don't put off the work until you feel rushed. The earlier you begin tackling the workload, the better off you will feel about not being rushed at the end of the semester.
It is a lot of time and effort, but well worth it, especially for MFs.

You will learn an enormous amount of information, develop practical skills, and come out of the course with a professional experience that can translate to numerous career fields. The course is invaluable.

Get ready, this will be the most challenging thing you do during your time at FES. It's an amazing experience, but as Dr. Ashton says, it's a marathon, not a sprint. If you fall behind or struggle, don't worry, there will be time to catch up and redeem yourself. But of course, do your best to keep up!

This course gives you tremendous skills and knowledge, but also comes at a cost. Its workload is intense and will likely take away from other learning opportunities (coursework, paid work, and otherwise). I learned a great deal, but was often frustrated that it took away from my engagement in other courses that I enjoyed just as much. Unless the course is split into two semesters, I would caution future class participants that it is a huge commitment with both great rewards and sacrifices on the other side.
If you're interested in forest and land management and are prepared for the heavy workload, take this class! You'll learn a ton.
absolutely take this class!!!
Make sure your the other classes you take during the same term are not too intellectually demanding because management plans takes a lot of work.

This course will take up A LOT of time. It's intimidating, but it's perfectly doable. You'll gain so much important knowledge that it's worth it. Just be ready for a serious slog. Get sampling out of the way as early as you can and save social research for later in the season, when the trees have lost their leaves.

To really consider that the commitment will exceed the six-credits and that ideally at least one person in their team should have a car. This is not a course requirement but does seem to facilitate access to the field in general.
Chose other courses that don't have too many time requirements. You will spend so much time on this class. Pace yourself.

Seriously consider if this class provides you the type of skills and learning you need--and conversely, if you truly have the necessary background to handle it. This class is not worth it if you don't intend to work with private landowners on managing their lands. Do not expect to get a ton of new skills from it since often your team will be so busy that you all will fall back on doing the things you already know how to do for efficiency's sake. Take courses with an easy workload, as this class is more than 6 credits worth of time and energy.
